It's 2025 and I am finally watching The Usual Suspects. Despite my common use of the phrase, especially when calling out my friends, I had never really considered watching the actual film. I also had never heard much about it, other than the lineup scene (why didn't they sing "I Want It That Way?"), and in the world of spoilers I thought "Great. Let me watch it, instantly, before I get spoiled." I was craving some kind of crime movie with a good plot twist and some comedy, and The Usual Suspects delivered. Almost.While I appreciated the movie greatly, acting being superb, the directing fiery and so nostalgic, the dialogue fun and quippy and basically almost everything about this movie being amazingly entertaining, I find that it fell flat on only one main account.Now, I'm not sure if, perhaps, the plot was more revolutionary back in 1995, but I'm reluctant to believe that viewers of the 90s were much dumber than I am today. The plot twist was... glaringly obvious? Is that a bit extreme? Well, it was quite obvious from very early on in the movie. I won't say what the plot twist was but if you get 20-30 minutes in and you don't suspect one particularly person... you will definitely suspect them by the mid way point.As soon as Keyser Söze (fabulous, name by the way, haha) is mentioned, as a seasoned movie watcher and enjoyer of good plot twists, it's kind of obvious what is going to happen.Perhaps I'm not aware (as I was not alive in the 90s) of the nature of crime stories during this period, but truly, the twist was so obvious it nearly, nearly ruined the experience for me.I still believe it was written really well and, of course, figuring out the twist early helps you to see all the slight signs pointing to its reveal at the end, saving you from a second watch (although, I would not mind one. The movie is quite fun.)The cinematography was great, acting wonderful and, shockingly, of the languages I did understand, (Hungarian is not one of them, so I can't speak for that) the actors did a surprisingly good job. I was impressed. Not too sure about Kobayashi's accent though... where was he meant to be from? Pakistan? Because... let me tell you he did not sound like he was from earth 😂. Perhaps a british man trying to sound... American? Pakistani? I don't know. But it added to my enjoyment because I got an extra laugh in every time he spoke. Keaton also had an interesting accent but it wasn't that bad.Other than those things, the movie was fun, satisfying, interesting. I just do wish the plot twist was more difficult to guess. But we can't all be The Sixth Sense. And I don't think it was a badly written plot twist at all, it did entirely make sense. I just hate that it was so obvious. I guessed it and didn't even doubt my guess at any point. But still, great fun! And glad I finally saw the iconic lineup scene - hilarious. Would recommend it just for that scene.

I've seen "The Usual Suspects" several times since its release so it's somewhat difficult for me to judge it now. After all, once one unravels the film's central mystery it cannot possibly produce the same reaction again. That being said, the film is one of those instances whereby a repeat viewing is rewarding since actions and events take on a different meaning.The cast is surprisingly good for a low-budget film. Securing Gabriel Byrne was a coup and Kevin Spacey delivered the goods in an Academy Award-winning performance. The rest of the cast includes dependable character actors like Pete Postlethwaite, Chazz Palminteri, Giancarlo Esposito & Dan Hedaya. Benicio del Toro stands out in a memorable supporting role but I have to say that Stephen Baldwin & Kevin Pollak leave something to be desired. Nevertheless, on the whole, the acting is in good hands.However, it's the screenplay that justifiably gets most of the credit for making this film memorable. Opening with the aftermath of an apparent drug deal gone wrong, we're led through the preceding events as related by 'Verbal' Kint (Kevin Spacey). He tells of how the titular 'usual suspects' got together and how they came to be embroiled in a mystery that has the cops baffled. All of this leads to a climax that I can only say I hope no-one has spoiled for you.On the technical side, Bryan Singer's direction is well-handled as he manages to imbue the film with a distinct sense of style without going overboard. Editor John Ottman also scored the picture and he did a fine job on both counts. The efforts of Singer & Ottman give the film a polish that defies its relatively low budget.Ultimately, it's difficult for me to judge this film (or any film with a twist) since I've seen it multiple times. That being said, the fact that I have seen it multiple times shows that the vaunted twist is only a part of the film's appeal. Nevertheless, for a first time viewing I'd be tempted to bump the film's rating up to a 9 out of 10.

The Usual Suspects is one of those rare films that doesn't just entertain; it completely transforms the way we think about storytelling in cinema. From the moment the film begins, director Bryan Singer, with a screenplay by Christopher McQuarrie, pulls the audience into a world of intrigue, danger, and deception-creating a cinematic experience that is as intellectually engaging as it is thrilling. This neo-noir masterpiece keeps you questioning everything, only to deliver a mind-blowing conclusion that reshapes everything you've just seen.At the heart of The Usual Suspects is its genius narrative structure. The film centers around a group of criminals who are brought together for a heist gone wrong. The story is told primarily through the unreliable narration of Verbal Kint (Kevin Spacey), a small-time crook who seems to be the only one left to tell the tale. The way the film manipulates time, memory, and perspective is what makes it so captivating. What we see on screen is not always what is happening in the "real" story, forcing the audience to constantly reevaluate what they think they know. The layers of deception are gradually peeled back, each new revelation adding to the mystery, while keeping the truth tantalizingly out of reach. This approach not only makes The Usual Suspects a puzzle to solve, but also a meditation on the nature of truth and memory.Spacey's portrayal of Verbal Kint is nothing short of a masterclass in acting. He brings a layer of vulnerability to the character, making him immediately sympathetic-someone you believe to be an easy mark, and yet, as the story unfolds, you begin to wonder if you've been seeing him for who he truly is. Spacey's nuanced performance keeps us on edge, never fully letting us trust his version of events, while still making us care about his fate. The subtlety with which Spacey plays the role-mixing fear with charm and manipulation-adds a chilling complexity to the character, making him unforgettable long after the film ends.Equally important are the other characters in the ensemble cast, each bringing their own unique energy to the film. Gabriel Byrne, Benicio del Toro, and Stephen Baldwin all turn in stellar performances as members of the criminal group. The dynamics between these characters-strained, tense, and full of underlying mistrust-are the perfect backdrop for the intricate web of lies that Verbal weaves. Each actor plays their part with skill, bringing depth to their characters, even when they are not the primary focus of the story.The mystery at the center of The Usual Suspects is, of course, the legendary criminal mastermind, Keyser Söze. The name alone carries a heavy weight in the world the film creates, as Söze is a figure of such fear and mythic proportions that no one is ever quite sure if he is real or just a figment of the imagination. The film explores the power of legend and reputation-how a person can become larger than life, even if they don't physically exist. Throughout the film, the mere mention of Söze's name sends ripples of terror, revealing how perception can often shape reality in the most terrifying of ways. This exploration of myth vs. Truth adds another layer of complexity to the story and enriches the themes of deception and identity.From a technical perspective, The Usual Suspects shines in every department. The cinematography, helmed by Newton Thomas Sigel, sets the perfect tone for the film. The moody lighting and dark, shadowy visuals add to the sense of danger and uncertainty that permeates the story. The soundtrack works in harmony with the film's pace, moving the story along with an undercurrent of menace that never lets up.But perhaps the most memorable and impactful element of The Usual Suspects is its legendary twist ending. It's nearly impossible to discuss the film without mentioning the final moments, which completely redefine everything the audience has experienced up to that point. The twist is a masterstroke in storytelling-clever, bold, and utterly satisfying. It's the kind of ending that leaves you rethinking every single moment you've seen, piecing together clues you missed the first time around. Instead, it feels earned, and when the pieces finally fall into place, it's a jaw-dropping moment that resonates with the viewer long after the credits roll.The film's themes-deception, identity, and the power of perception-are all tied together so seamlessly, and the way they are explored through the characters and their actions is both thought-provoking and thrilling. It's a film that encourages multiple viewings because each time you watch, you discover something new. The complexity of the plot, the depth of the characters, and the intricacy of the narrative ensure that The Usual Suspects remains as fresh and impactful with each new viewing as it was the first time.In conclusion, The Usual Suspects is a film that is nothing short of a cinematic masterpiece. With its brilliant narrative structure, unforgettable performances, and a twist ending that has become legendary in film history, it stands as one of the best thrillers ever made. So they bring in five of the Big Apple's best known thieves to shake the underworld's tree. But unbeknownst to the police, or our "suspects," there are greater forces at play. When it's all said and done, LAPD, NYPD, and the feds are left sifting through an abandoned cargo ship in an L.A. harbor with lots of bodies but not much else. All they have to go on is the shaky story of a talkative small-time crook named Verbal Kint (Kevin Spacey, who won an Oscar for best supporting actor for the role), and a dying victim of the shootout who claims to have seen the devil incarnate on the ship, a legendary criminal kingpin whose name sends shivers up the spines of police and lawbreakers alike. It may not sound like much, but every aspect of this film comes off so astoundingly well, from the morose cinematography and foreboding score, to the impeccable performances by its stars (Spacey, Gabriel Byrne, Stephen Baldwin, Kevin Pollak, and Benicio Del Toro as the "suspects" and Chazz Palminteri as the federal agent trying to piece their story together), The Usual Suspects concludes with a classic stunner that only adds to its reputation as one of the greatest crime dramas ever filmed, if not the best ever.

Released in 1995 and directed by Bryan Singer, "The Usual Suspects" is a crime drama/mystery about five thugs who decide to team up and get revenge on the police (Keven Spacey, Gabriel Byrne, Steve Baldwin, Keven Pollak and Benicio Del Toro). Moreover, the main characters are just foul-mouthed, tough-guy low-lifes, although Spacey's character is somewhat interesting. As such, it's next to impossible to care about them. As far as the twist goes, I was able to pinpoint the identity of the mystery man down to two people; and I was right. But there are some interesting details to the twist that I doubt anyone could figure out without first knowing the ending and then re-watching the flick. But, after watching, I'm not interested in seeing it again. The story and the characters aren't worth it. The film didn't make me care enough to watch again.Filmmakers must understand that, for a movie to be enduring, it has to be about the journey not the destination. And, for me, the convoluted journey in "The Usual Suspects" is just dull and laborious. If the characters were worthy and I cared about them I might be more interested, but that's not the case. Then there's something that I experienced a couple of times while observing the five main guys babble back and forth: I had the overwhelming sense that these were just actors playing 'hip' tough-tawkin' hooligans rather than the characters they were supposed to be. The Usual Suspects is a 1995 Crime-Thriller directed by Bryan Singer. The film stars Kevin Spacey, Benicio Del Toro, Stephen Baldwin, Gabriel Byrne, and Kevin Pollak as the film's group of hardened criminals. The film follows Kevin Spacey's character, Roger "Verbal" Knit as he narrates a series of crimes to the Police to find the truth of a high scale massacre.The acting in the film is hit or miss. For the most part, the main cast does a great job in the portrayal of their characters. Kevin Spacey's portrayal of Verbal is well done. Verbal has a physical disability and is considered to be stupid. Spacey displays a convincing lack of mobility in the film. Simultaneously, Spacey's body language is believably timid and mild manner. Moreover, Benicio Del Toro's portrayal of Fred Fenster was fantastic. Del Toro engrains Fenster with a thick accent that lends a realistic and natural spirit to the character. Gabriel Byrne plays Dean Keaton, serving as the assumed leader of the criminals. Byrne's portrayal of Keaton grants the film levity and a cooler head. Byrne's facial expressions are really well done. Keaton is a character tormented by his past. Despite being haunted, Keaton serves as the straight man, driven by love as opposed to gain. Chazz Palminteri acts as Officer, Dave Kujan. Palminteri does a great job showcasing intensity and grit when needed. He drives the film by answering the questions when needed. Despite moments of great acting, the dialogue suffers from poor writing and delivery in some aspects.Some characters are one-dimensional. Certain actors deliver their lines with too much force and intensity. Verbal has the best dialogue in the film. "The greatest trick that the devil ever pulled was making people believe he didn't exist," is an incredible line. The police officers in the film are also afforded some great lines, and engaging moments of discourse. At times, anger throughout the film feels unnecessary. In terms of being written, specific characters are very dumb, whereas others are brilliant. The aggression in the film is heavy handed at moments, diluting the story's progression. Up until the conclusion, the story is convoluted and predictable. The time jumps and flashbacks are placed poorly at moments. The story could've benefited from more "present day" moments, rather than flashbacks. On the other hand, the ending makes up for a lot of these issues by being so impactful. The convolution of the story is a testament to who is truly narrating it.The cinematography is decent for its time. Mostly, there's no unique style to be had in the cinematography. The camera work is atypical for an action film in the 90s. The best shot moments in the film come from the conclusion. The action in this film is decent. The audio mixing is bright toward the end of the film. However, the soundtrack is very bland, making the film feel like a direct to TV movie, as opposed to a theatrical release.Overall, The Usual Suspects is confusing at first, but recoups with an iconic and memorable ending. The Usual Suspects is a good crime-thriller driven by great acting.

Usual Suspects made a long career for Bryan Singer, and an even larger reputation for itself. A crime-thriller that supposedly pioneered the 'shocking' twist, long before Shyamalan came on the scene. But what about watching a movie without any pre-conceived notions? I took the time to slip it into the DVD player with my old man besides me. After 2 hours of convoluted trickery, he was less than impressed with the film's main plot device. "Well that was clever..... but is that it?"With a combination of tropes (the dog being the mastermind, crossed with unreliable narrator) the writers try to keep the audience guessing, but somewhat superficially, as the story gradually winds down to a less than mind-blowing finale. The direction is flashy and Scorsese-lite, with bright lighting, wide angles, and mysterious music to let the viewer feel he is being led astray. It works for the most part, but I felt like my buttons were being pressed unwillingly by the filmmaker, to make the mystery seem thicker than it was.The other problem was the narrator-bound narrative. It was essential for the plot, but also meant we never peek into the lives of these characters we're supposed to be attached to. The history between them is relegated to expository dialogue, and a love-interest's death is dealt out in an offhand fashion right at the climax. It made me realize that most of the story is built around this twist ending, and the rest of what happened in the film, all the mini-adventures the characters had, the elaborate trail they had been lead on, was all window-dressing to get me to the WOW shocker that had been promised all along.It's neat, artfully told, smooth film making, but the story seems like it could have been condensed into a 20 minute Twilight Zone episode and left at that. Not a 2 hour feature. My time wasn't exactly wasted, but there wasn't much meat to chew on, thematically or character-wise, and all it left me to ponder upon was a quote hijacked from French poet Charles Baudelair; "The devil's finest trick is to persuade you that he does not exist." It doesn't exactly scream originality, does it? Shouldn't the writers have to pay copyright material for using another's work?

Every bad review of this film can be summed in one question: "what's the point of watching the entire movie if it's all just made up?!"The problem with this view is, of course, that it fails to appreciate that The Usual Suspects is a MOVIE. Every movie has a narrator. Some narrators tell part of the story by talking (e.g. The Shawshank Redemption). Some tell part of the story by writing (e.g. Star Wars). The vast majority of narrators don't talk or write, they just show--no voice over, no text at the bottom of the screen saying "Somewhere in the Atlantic Ocean." A few movies have a narrator within the narration. The Princess Bride, for example, tells the story of a grandfather telling a story. We appreciate the story-within-a-story plot of that film because it draws us in from the beginning.But one thing that all these movies have in common is that they're movies. They are fictional stories told through a visual/auditory medium. The fact that none of it is true doesn't make a movie any less spectacular. Take Saving Private Ryan for example--does it take away from the movie knowing that the story behind it is completely fabricated?This is what the naysayers tend to miss about The Usual Suspects--like any movie, it tells a fiction...but UNLIKE most other movies, this one goes a step further and ADMITS that the whole story was made up. That is, the "outer" narrator (the all-seeing, all-knowing camera), shows you that the "inner" narrator (Verbal) was lying through his nose.This doesn't make the film worse...it makes it better. It reminds the viewer how gullible people are. The living proof is the people who criticize the movie for not being clear about what really happened. As if "what really happened" really happened. Newsflash: it didn't...this is fiction.Of the many reasons why The Usual Suspects is a great movie, here's the one that I'm trying to point out with this post: The film makes you believe that it is a story about a master criminal. Then you find out that it's a story about a master storyteller (who just happens to be a master criminal).
